key_issues: The petitioner's request for adjournment was rejected by the Intellectual Property Appellate Board due to misrepresentation of facts.
The petitioner's counsel was found to have made false claims of being in self-quarantine due to COVID-19, while social media evidence showed they were on holiday.
The Intellectual Property Appellate Board has the power to dismiss adjournment applications with costs for misrepresentation.
The Board can report instances of professional misconduct to the Bar Council of India for appropriate action.
The petitioner had sought rectification of trademark registrations, which were allowed by the Board on merits.
The petitioner had argued before the Board, but their arguments were not found sufficient to warrant a favorable decision.
The use of social media evidence to discredit a party's claims is a valid legal tactic.
The Intellectual Property Appellate Board has the authority to impose costs on a party for frivolous or misleading claims.
The rejection of the adjournment application was based on the Board's discretion and the petitioner's history of non-representation at previous hearings.
The petitioner's failure to successfully argue their case before the Board led to the rectification of the trademark registrations in favor of the respondent.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board and Ors.**

**Background:**

The case involves a writ petition filed by Vinod Kumar under Article 226 of the Constitution of India, challenging an order dated December 30, 2020, passed by the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) in Rectification Petitions ORA/108/2020/TM/DEL and ORA/117/2020/TM/DEL. The petitioner was the respondent before the IPAB, and the rectification petitions were filed by the respondent (FK Bearing Group Co. Ltd.) against the petitioner.

**Legal Issues:**

The primary issue in this case is the rejection of an adjournment petition by the IPAB, which led to the IPAB passing an order allowing the rectification petitions on merit. The petitioner's counsel had requested an adjournment due to COVID-19 restrictions, stating that their office was closed, and the main arguing counsel was in self-quarantine. However, the IPAB found that this representation was false, as evidenced by the counsel's Facebook posts, which showed that he was on holiday during the relevant period.

**Arguments:**

The petitioner's counsel argued that the adjournment petition was genuine and that the Facebook posts were not relevant to the merits of the case. The respondent's counsel, on the other hand, argued that the adjournment petition was an attempt to delay the proceedings and that the false representation was made with the intent to secure an adjournment.

**Court Findings:**

The IPAB found that the adjournment petition was an attempt to mislead the court and that the false representation was made with the intent to secure an adjournment. The IPAB also found that the counsel's Facebook posts were evidence of his lack of credibility. The IPAB, therefore, rejected the adjournment petition, allowed the rectification petitions on merit, and awarded costs against the petitioner's counsel.

**Decision:**

The High Court of Delhi, in its judgment dated December 12, 2022, considered the petitioner's challenge to the IPAB's order. The court noted that the IPAB had passed directions against the learned counsel for making false averments before it and had also awarded costs and referred the matter to the Bar Council of India in the event of failure to pay the costs. The court's decision in this case is not provided in the given pages, and therefore, the final outcome of the case remains unknown.

**Key Takeaways:**

1. The case highlights the importance of credibility and honesty in legal proceedings.
2. The IPAB's decision to reject the adjournment petition and allow the rectification petitions on merit was based on the finding that the petitioner's counsel had made false representations.
3. The case also underscores the consequences of making false representations before a court or tribunal, including the imposition of costs and potential referral to the Bar Council of India.

1. 
This writ petition, under Article 226 of the Constitution of India, 
assails order dated 30th December 2020 passed by the learned Intellectual 
Property Appellate Board (the learned IPAB) in Rectification Petitions 
ORA/108/2020/TM/DEL and ORA/117/2020/TM/DEL (FK Bearing 
Group Co. Ltd. v. Vinod Kumar & Anr.) The petitioner was Respondent 
1 before the learned IPAB and Respondent 2 herein was the appellant. 
The rectification petitions were, therefore, instituted by Respondent 2 
against the petitioner. 
 
2. 
The impugned order allows the rectifications petitions filed by 
Respondent 2 on merits. 
 
3. 
Before the learned IPAB, the petitioner had sought an 
adjournment. The adjournment was rejected by the learned IPAB. Para 3

of the impugned order dated 30th December 2020, which deals with the 
said request, reads thus: 
 
“There is no representation on behalf of the Respondent No.1 at this 
and on the last few hearings and the matter today came up for final 
hearing of the on 29th December 2020; there was an adjournment 
petition filed by the Respondent No.1 and one counsel Mr. Abhilash 
Gupta (Enrollment No.D/3897/2019) on behalf of Suwarn Rajan 
Chauhan 
(Enrollment 
No.D/667/2000) 
& 
Akshay 
Srivastava 
(Enrollment No.D/1967/2008) represented and informed the counsel's 
office is closed due to covid-19 and the employees are isolated to their 
residences and the main arguing counsel is also directed to be in self-
quarantine 
till 
01-01-2021; 
the 
Respondent 
in 
adjournment 
petition/Rectification Applicant filed its counter and annexed the 
Facebook page of the Mr. Akshay Srivastava who is lead counsel in 
the matter. In the said Facebook page of Mr. Akshay Srivastava the 
status is updated has been travelling for a holiday since 24.12.2020 to 
Tirupati, Rameswaram, Maduria and the last activity shown on his 
Facebook account is that he was at Marina Beach, Chennai on 
27.12.2020 screen shots of his Facebook profile clearly exhibited the 
same. In light of the same it is falsely represented before this Board 
that the main counsel is in quarantine while it has been shown to us 
through the Facebook postings that the said Counsel is on a holiday, 
we have no reason not to believe the said representation by the 
Respondent/Rectification Applicant pointing out through the Facebook 
printouts. It is a matter of regret that such irresponsible false 
representations are made before this Board. This sought of 
misrepresentations are unwarranted and does not go well with the bar 
and bench, we may be constrained to report this sought of reckless 
submissions to the Bar Council. Since a deliberate wrong irresponsible 
representation has been before us with an intent to secure an 
adjournment in the matter the said Adjournment application is being 
dismissed with costs of Rs.5,000/ -. The same may be deposited with 
PM Cares fund at the earliest not before 07th January 2021 and the 
deposit slip be filed with this Board failing which we shall report to 
Bar Council of India to take appropriate action against the said 
counsels Suwarn Rajan Chauhan (Enrollment No.D/667/2000) & 
Akshay Srivastava (Enrollment No.D/1967/2008).” 
 
4. 
The learned IPAB proceeded to pass directions against learned 
Counsel for having, as it thought, made false averments before it with 
respect to availability of learned Counsel.  It has also awarded costs and 
has referred the matter to the Bar Council of India in the event of failure 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:13.12.2022
15:36:20
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
Neutral Citation Number :2022/DHC/005508 
CS(COMM) 310/2020                                                                                               Page 3 of 6 
 
to pay the costs imposed. 
 
5. 
In the present petition, this Court, vide order dated 23rd February 
2021, directed the learned Counsel who had been appearing in the matter 
before the learned IPAB to file individual affidavits, explaining their 
failure to be present before the learned IPAB on 30th December 2020. 
 
6. 
Three learned Counsel were appearing on behalf of Respondent 1 
before the learned IPAB, namely Abhilash Gupta, Akshay Srivastava and 
Suwarn Rajan Chauhan. As is apparent from para 3 of the impugned 
order, the learned IPAB proceeded on the premise that Akshay Srivastava 
was the lead Counsel. Save and except a statement to the said effect 
having been made by learned Counsel for Respondent 2, there appears to 
be no justification for the learned IPAB’s presumption that Akshay 
Srivastava was the lead Counsel in the matter. 
 
7. 
Before this Court, it has been submitted that the arguing Counsel 
before the learned IPAB was Suwarn Rajan Chauhan who was indeed 
under quarantine and expired on 30th April 2021. 
 
8. 
This Court has also seen some of the earlier orders passed by the 
learned IPAB in the said proceedings in which it does appear that Suwarn 
Rajan Chauhan was principally appearing on behalf of the petitioner. 
 
9. 
In that view of the matter, this Court is unable to sustain the 
impugned order, insofar as it refused to adjourn the matter on the premise 
that Akshay Srivastava was the lead Counsel and that he was at Chennai 
on the date when the matter was taken up. 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:13.12.2022
15:36:20
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
Neutral Citation Number :2022/DHC/005508 
CS(COMM) 310/2020                                                                                               Page 4 of 6 
 
 
10. 
Even otherwise, in my considered opinion, before taking an 
adverse view against the Counsel on the basis of a Facebook post, and 
referring the matter to the Bar Council of India, the learned IPAB ought, 
at the very least, to have given an opportunity to the Counsel to explain 
the circumstances. Postings on Facebook cannot be treated as 
determinative of the location of a person at a particular point of time, at 
least by a Court. Even if a Court is to take an adverse view in that regard, 
the Counsel ought to be given an opportunity to explain the position 
before such a view is taken. This Court is of the concerned opinion that 
the learned IPAB was needlessly strict in imposing costs and referring 
the matter to the Bar Council of India in such circumstances. 
 
11. 
In view of the fact that Suwarn Rajan Chauhan was indeed 
quarantined at the relevant time and expired, unfortunately, thereafter, 
this Court is not entering into any of the other aspects of the matter 
regarding non-absence of Counsel on behalf of the petitioner on 30th 
December 2020. 
 
12. 
So far as the earlier adjournments taken by the petitioner, if any, 
are concerned, the matter stands covered by the following passage from 
the judgment of the Supreme Court in State Bank of India v. Chandra 
Govind Ji1: 
 
“7. 
In ascertaining whether a party had reasonable 
opportunity to put forward his case or not, one should not 
ordinarily go beyond the date on which adjournment is 
sought for. The earlier adjournment, if any, granted would 
certainly be for reasonable grounds and that aspect need not 
                                          
1 (2000) 8 SCC 532 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:13.12.2022
15:36:20
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number :2022/DHC/005508 
CS(COMM) 310/2020                                                                                               Page 5 of 6 
 
be once again examined if on the date on which adjournment 
is sought for the party concerned has a reasonable ground. 
The mere fact that in the past adjournments had been sought 
for would not be of any materiality. If the adjournment had 
been sought for on flimsy grounds the same would have been 
rejected. Therefore, in our view, the High Court as well as the 
learned District Judge and the Rent Controller have all 
missed the essence of the matter.” 
 
13. 
In view of the aforesaid discussion, the impugned order dated 30th 
December 2020 is quashed and set aside. The rectification petitions filed 
by Respondent 2 shall stand restored for re-hearing.  
 
14. 
Inasmuch as the learned IPAB has subsequently been abolished, 
the rectification petitions would have to be heard by this Court. The 
Registry is directed to register the rectification petitions under the 
appropriate nomenclature and list them before the Court on 23rd February 
2023 for hearing and disposal. Let the record from the learned IPAB be 
also requisitioned prior to the said date. 
 
15. 
For the purpose of registration, the Respondent 2 is directed to 
place on record a photocopy of the entire record along with an 
appropriate affidavit under Section 65-B of the Evidence Act, 1872. 
Respondent 2 undertakes to provide the registry with the entire record of 
the rectification petitions filed before the learned IPAB within a period of 
four weeks. On the said record being provided the rectification petitions 
would be numbered and registered before this Court and listed before the 
Court for disposal on 23rd February 2023. 
 
16. 
Mr. Siddharth Bamba learned Counsel for Respondent 2 points out 
that, Respondent 2 was enjoying interim relief vide order dated 10th July 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:13.12.2022
15:36:20
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number :2022/DHC/005508 
CS(COMM) 310/2020                                                                                               Page 6 of 6 
 
2020 passed by the learned IPAB which was in force till the passing of 
the impugned order dated 30th December 2020. 
 
17. 
As the impugned order, which is in favour of Respondent 2, has 
been quashed only on the ground of violation of the principles of natural 
justice, Respondent 2 would be entitled to be restored to the position in 
which it was at the time of its passing. 
 
18. 
As such, the order dated 10th July 2020 passed by the learned 
IPAB shall stand restored and remain in operation till this Court decides 
the two rectification petitions. 
 
19. 
List the rectification petitions, duly registered, for hearing and 
disposal on 23rd February 2023. 
 
20. 
This writ petition stands allowed accordingly.  No costs. 
 
 
 
C.HARI SHANKAR, J

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board & Ors.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard the case W.P.(C)-IPD 50/2021 & CM APPL. 7338/2021. The petitioner, Vinod Kumar, was represented by Mr. Prince Arora, Advocate, while the respondents, Intellectual Property Appellate Board and others, were represented by Mr. Siddhar. 

The background and facts of the case reveal that the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) had imposed costs on the petitioner due to the absence of his counsel on December 30, 2020. The petitioner's counsel, Suwarn Rajan Chauhan, was under quarantine and later expired on April 30, 2021. However, the IPAB presumed that Akshay Srivastava was the lead counsel and proceeded with the case.

The High Court of Delhi, however, found that Suwarn Rajan Chauhan was the arguing counsel and was principally appearing on behalf of the petitioner. The court also reviewed earlier orders passed by the IPAB, which confirmed Chauhan's role as the lead counsel. 

As a result, the High Court was unable to sustain the IPAB's order, which had refused to adjourn the matter due to the presumed absence of the lead counsel, Akshay Srivastava. The court's decision was made on February 23, 2021, and was digitally signed by Kamla Rawat on December 13, 2022. The details of the case can be found in the PDF document, which bears the Neutral Citation Number: 2022/DHC/005508.

tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board & Ors.pdf", the legal proceedings involve a petition filed by Vinod Kumar against the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) and others. The case, W.P.(C)-IPD 50/2021 & CM APPL. 7338/2021, was heard in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi. 

The petitioner's counsel, Mr. Prince Arora, argued that the IPAB had taken an adverse view against the counsel based on a Facebook post, referring the matter to the Bar Council of India without giving the counsel an opportunity to explain. The court agreed, stating that postings on Facebook cannot be treated as determinative of a person's location at a particular point in time.

The court also considered the fact that a person, Suwarn Rajan Chauhan, was quarantined and later expired, and therefore did not enter into other aspects of the matter regarding the non-absence of counsel on behalf of the petitioner on December 30, 2020.

The court quashed and set aside the impugned order dated December 30, 2020, and restored the rectification petitions filed by Respondent 2 for re-hearing. As the IPAB has been abolished, the rectification petitions will be heard by the High Court. The registry was directed to register the petitions and list them for hearing on February 23, 2023. (Source: Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board & Ors.pdf)

the circumstances. Postings on Facebook cannot be treated as 
determinative of the location of a person at a particular point of time, at 
least by a Court. Even if a Court is to take an adverse view in that regard, 
the Counsel ought to be given an opportunity to explain the position 
before such a view is taken. This Court is of the concerned opinion that 
the learned IPAB was needlessly strict in imposing costs and referring 
the matter to the Bar Council of India in such circumstances. 
 
11. 
In view of the fact that Suwarn Rajan Chauhan was indeed 
quarantined at the relevant time and expired, unfortunately, thereafter, 
this Court is not entering into any of the other aspects of the matter 
regarding non-absence of Counsel on behalf of the petitioner on 30th 
December 2020. 
 
12. 
So far as the earlier adjournments taken by the petitioner, if any, 
are concerned, the matter stands covered by the following passage from 
the judgment of the Supreme Court in State Bank of India v. Chandra 
Govind Ji1: 
 
“7. 
In ascertaining whether a party had reasonable 
opportunity to put forward his case or not, one should not 
ordinarily go beyond the date on which adjournment is 
sought for. The earlier adjournment, if any, granted would 
certainly be for reasonable grounds and that aspect need not

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF "48. Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board & Ors.pdf", the court decided to quash the impugned order dated December 30, 2020, due to a violation of natural justice principles. As a result, the order dated July 10, 2020, passed by the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) will be restored and remain in operation until the court decides on the two rectification petitions. The rectification petitions are scheduled for hearing and disposal on February 23, 2023. The writ petition was allowed without costs. The decision was made by Judge C. Hari Shankar on December 12, 2022. (Source: "48. Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board & Ors.pdf", page 6)

17. 
As the impugned order, which is in favour of Respondent 2, has 
been quashed only on the ground of violation of the principles of natural 
justice, Respondent 2 would be entitled to be restored to the position in 
which it was at the time of its passing. 
 
18. 
As such, the order dated 10th July 2020 passed by the learned 
IPAB shall stand restored and remain in operation till this Court decides 
the two rectification petitions. 
 
19.

20.
